title: Natural Classic: The Golden Hawks
subtitle: Martha Holmes, marine biologist, TV presenter and film producer, on the book that most influenced her.

cards.text: I'm a very keen reader, but selecting the book with a natural-history theme which has influenced me most was some challenge, until I thought back to my childhood. Then it was easy.
cards.question: When first asked to choose a book, Martha Holmes
choices: chose one she had read recently.
had difficulty in making a decision.
was pleased to have been approached.
cards.highlight: was some challenge, until I thought back to my childhood

cards.text: Where the book came from is a mystery, and I have never met anyone who has heard of it. It is Rita Richie's The Golden Hawks of Genghis Khan.
cards.question: What does 'it' in line 9 refer to?
cards.highlight: It is Rita Richie's The Golden Hawks of Genghis Khan

cards.text: Set in 1218, it is a story of a rich boy whose parents are dead. He is growing up in the splendid city of Samarkand and has a fascination for hawks, those magnificent hunting birds.
cards.question: Martha says the book The Golden Hawks of Genghis Khan
choices: was very popular when she was a child.
is known to very few people.
is one of many mystery books she has read.
cards.highlight: I have never met anyone who has heard of it.

cards.text: There is a great deal of mystery surrounding his past, but he is led to believe that a band of Mongols killed his father to steal a rare type of birdâ€”the golden hawk... Determined to get these birds back, he runs away from Samarkand and joins a group of people travelling in the country of Mongolia.
cards.question: The main interest of the hero of the book is
choices: the desire to see different countries.

cards.text: What follows is a grand adventure centred on the city of Karakorum, where the great Mongol chief Genghis Khan was then based.
cards.question: Where does most of the story take place?
cards.highlight: a grand adventure centred on the city of Karakorum

cards.text: But most of all it was the sense of place that stayed with me. The book gives the reader an idea of the vast open spaces of central Asia and its huge skies, without the use of the long descriptive passages that would bore a child.
cards.question: What did Martha enjoy about the book?
cards.highlight: it was the sense of place that stayed with me... the vast open spaces

cards.text: The Mongols in The Golden Hawks were totally uninterested in possessions... Generosity, goodwill and optimism were highly valued, hard work was enjoyed and the rest was pure fun.
cards.question: What values did Martha learn from the book?
choices: the importance of a sense of humour
how to be a successful traveller
the need to protect your goods
how to get the most out of life
cards.highlight: Generosity, goodwill, and optimism were highly valued... They simply loved life.
